<Link id="l00062" /><CodeLine lineNumber="62"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00063" /><CodeLine lineNumber="63"><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">private</span><span class="doxyHighlight">:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00064" /><CodeLine lineNumber="64"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Replace the original RET instruction with the exit sled code (&quot;patchable</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00065" /><CodeLine lineNumber="65"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   ret&quot; pseudo-instruction), so that at runtime XRay can replace the sled</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00066" /><CodeLine lineNumber="66"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   with a code jumping to XRay trampoline, which calls the tracing handler</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00067" /><CodeLine lineNumber="67"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   and, in the end, issues the RET instruction.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00068" /><CodeLine lineNumber="68"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// This is the approach to go on CPUs which have a single RET instruction,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00069" /><CodeLine lineNumber="69"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   like x86/x86&#95;64.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00070" /><CodeLine lineNumber="70"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">void</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> replaceRetWithPatchableRet(<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machinefunction">MachineFunction</a> &amp;MF,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00071" /><CodeLine lineNumber="71"><span class="doxyHighlight">                                  </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">const</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/targetinstrinfo">TargetInstrInfo</a> &#42;<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/hexagon/hexagoncopytocombine-cpp/#a1d40004718218dbdf06b496766299101">TII</a>,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00072" /><CodeLine lineNumber="72"><span class="doxyHighlight">                                  <a href="/docs/api/structs/anonymous-namespace-xrayinstrumentation-cpp-/instrumentationoptions">InstrumentationOptions</a>);</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00073" /><CodeLine lineNumber="73"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00074" /><CodeLine lineNumber="74"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Prepend the original return instruction with the exit sled code (&quot;patchable</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00075" /><CodeLine lineNumber="75"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   function exit&quot; pseudo-instruction), preserving the original return</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00076" /><CodeLine lineNumber="76"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   instruction just after the exit sled code.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00077" /><CodeLine lineNumber="77"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// This is the approach to go on CPUs which have multiple options for the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00078" /><CodeLine lineNumber="78"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   return instruction, like ARM. For such CPUs we can&#39;t just jump into the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00079" /><CodeLine lineNumber="79"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   XRay trampoline and issue a single return instruction there. We rather</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00080" /><CodeLine lineNumber="80"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   have to call the trampoline and return from it to the original return</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00081" /><CodeLine lineNumber="81"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   instruction of the function being instrumented.</span></CodeLine>
